keywords.value: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
keywords.name: subject

lead_paragraph: As the Supreme Court prepares to hear oral arguments on same-sex marriage, Cincinnati has become the measure of how far the gay rights movement has come in a traditionally conservative city.

headline.print_headline: Gay Rights Case Caps Transition for Cincinnati
headline.main: Gay Marriage Case Caps Cincinnati’s Shift From Conservative Past

snippet: As the Supreme Court prepares to hear oral arguments on same-sex marriage, Cincinnati has become the measure of how far the gay rights movement has come in a traditionally conservative city.
abstract: Case filed by Jim Obergefell challenging Ohio's ban on same-sex marriage, which will go before Supreme Court, illustrates how far Cincinnati has come from its traditionally conservative roots; while city, where Obergefell and his now deceased partner John Arthur lived, is technically the defendant, its attorneys have refused to defend Ohio ban, and city's leaders frequently market it as friendly to homosexuals, bisexuals and transgender people.
